Intermediate ggplot2 workshop series




Wickham, Hadley. 2010. “A Layered Grammar of Graphics.” Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics 19 (1): 3–28. https://doi.org/10.1198/jcgs.2009.07098.


Wilkinson, Leland. 2005. The Grammar of Graphics. 2nd ed. Statistics and Computing. New York: Springer-Verlag. https://doi.org/10.1007/0-387-28695-0.

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Code-along script
Script for today’s examples.

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Learning Objectives

Implement principles of effective design using {ggplot}. Including:

Maximize data:ink ratio using themes and facets
Customize marks and channels using geoms and aes(thetics).
Use helper tools including cols4all and esquisse to make thoughtful visualization choices.
Work through an example as a group.

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
The {ggplot2} default

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point()

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
{theme_*}

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw()

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
{theme_*}

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_void()

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
{theme_*}
For a complete list of preset themes:

?theme_void

Or online here.

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
{theme_*}






Important


theme_bw() and theme_minimal can remove a lot of unnecessary ink with one fell swoop.
Use theme_set(theme_bw()) outside your plot code to set the theme for a whole script or notebook.

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Modify a theme

The preset themes either leave unnecessary ink, or remove necessary information.
The theme() function allows you to modify individual elements of a theme
The theme options are vast. We’ll break it down.

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Anatomy of theme

theme( <part of the plot> = <element_*(element_options)>)
Parts of the plot: axis, legend, panel, plot, strip.
Elements: element_blank, element_text, element_line, element_rect.

You can modify all lines/rectangles at once using theme(line = element_line()), etc.
See the rendered documentation to help you figure out how to change specific elements.

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Remove the background panel

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank())

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Re-add grid lines

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "black", linewidth = .5))

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Hierarchichal modifications

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  theme(panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "black", linewidth = .5))  +
  theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_line(color = "red", linewidth = .1))

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
facet_wrap

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_wrap(vars(island))

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
facet_wrap

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_wrap(vars(island), 
              ncol = 1)

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
facet_grid

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(island), 
              cols = vars(sex))

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Modify facet label placement

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(island), 
              cols = vars(sex), 
              switch = "y")

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Modify facet scales

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(island), 
              cols = vars(sex), 
              switch = "y", 
              scales = "free_y")

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Modify facet scales

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(island), 
              cols = vars(sex), 
              switch = "y", 
              scales = "free_y")







Important


Use judiciously!

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Modify facet strip options

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(island), 
              cols = vars(sex), 
              switch = "y") +
  theme(strip.background = element_blank())

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Move the legend

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(island), 
              cols = vars(sex), 
              switch = "y") +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Counterintuitive marks and channels
Size is much worse than position for showing continuous data!

ggplot(penguins, aes(sex, species, size = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_jitter() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank())

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Counterintuitive marks and channels
Size is much worse than position for showing continuous data!

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g)) +
  geom_histogram() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(species),
             cols = vars(sex), 
             switch = "y")

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Marks and channels: Options
Shape is less effective than color for differentiating categories!

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm, 
                     shape = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank())

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Marks and channels: Options
Shape is less effective than color for differentiating categories!

ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, 
                     bill_depth_mm, 
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.background = element_blank())

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Effective color scales

There are multitudes of color palettes available for R.
Color palettes can be sequential, categorical, diverging, or bivariate.
Not all color palettes will be equally accessible to all viewers.
Cols4All helps you explore color palettes and find one to meet your needs.

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
cols4all

install.packages("cols4all", dependencies = TRUE)

library(cols4all)

c4a_gui()

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
A data-to-viz helper: Esquisse

esquisse is a ggplot2 extension for exploring data-viz pairings
Stay tuned for session 3 for more on extensions!

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Esquisse demo

install.packages("esquisse")

esquisse::esquisser(penguins)

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Let’s put it together

Take a look at the “Measles” data table here.
Let’s think through a visualization we could make of these data. Ask:

Which data variables will tell a story? What types of data are they?
Which chart type(s) would be appropriate for these data types?
What marks and channels shall we use?
What additional design decisions could we make to improve the graphic?

text:
Resources

ggplot2 documentation
cols4all
esquisse

Data Science Incubator

title: Effective Data Communication With {ggplot2}
text:
Next up: ggplot2 extensions!
More information and register here.




Intermediate ggplot2 workshop series

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Learning Objectives

Understand where to find packages that extend ggplot2
Demonstrate some extension packages

Assemble multi-panel figures with patchwork
Make animated plots with gganimate
Visualize distributions with ggdist
Plot network data with ggraph

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Packages

library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins) #for example dataset
library(patchwork) #for multi-panel figures
library(gridGraphics) #for combining ggplot2 and base R figures
library(gganimate) #for animated plots
library(ggdist) #for showing distributions + uncertainty in data
library(dplyr) #for cleaning data
library(ggraph) #for network data

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
General-use and modular

library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggthemes)
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_beeswarm() +
  theme_economist()



geom_beeswarm() can easily be combined with other geom_s

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
“All-in-one” functions

library(ggstatsplot)
ggbetweenstats(penguins, species, body_mass_g) +
  scale_y_continuous("Body Mass (g)", n.breaks = 10)



With great power comes great responsibility—make sure you trust these stats!
Notice that the output is a ggplot object, so you can continue to add layers to it.

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Transformative & field-specific






ggspectra







gggenes

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Finding Extensions

Browse the ggplot2 extensions gallery
Check out the Awesome ggplot2 list
The R Graph Gallery
Google search with “ggplot2” keyword

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
patchwork
patchwork allows you to compose multi-panel figures with ease


Things to notice:

Plots areas are aligned despite one not having a y-axis label
Only one legend
Labels for panels A, B, C

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Example plots

p1 <- 
  ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, 
                       y = bill_length_mm, 
                       color = species)) +
  geom_point()
p2 <-
  ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_depth_mm, 
                       y = bill_length_mm, 
                       color = species)) +
  geom_point()
p3 <- 
  ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g)) + 
  facet_wrap(vars(island)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Combine plots

+ wraps plots
| combines plots horizontally
/ combines plots vertically
() can be used to nest operations

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Combine plots

(p1 | p2) / p3

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Combine guides
If plots have identical guides, you can combine them with plot_layout(guides = "collect")

p1 + p2 + plot_layout(guides = "collect")



identical means same scale, same title, same glyph

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Combining axes
As of the most recent version of patchwork (v1.2.0) you can also combine identical axes.

p1 + p2 + plot_layout(guides = "collect", axes = "collect")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Controlling layout
For more options for controlling layout, see the related vignette on the package website.

Adding empty areas
Inset plots
Adjusting widths and heights

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Tags
You can add “tags” to each panel with plot_annotation()

p1 + p2 + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A", tag_suffix = ")")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Modifying all panels
You can use the & operator instead of + to modify all elements of a multi-panel figure.

p1 + p2 & theme_bw() & scale_color_viridis_d()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Using with base R plots
You can even combine ggplot2 plots with base R plots with a special syntax

p1 + ~hist(penguins$bill_depth_mm, main = "")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
gganimate
Display transitions between states of a variable
Useful for showing trends in time series & spatial data






Advice from the experts!


“Graphic elements should only transition between instances of the same underlying phenomenon”

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Example
Body size distribution of penguins changing over the years

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, col = species)) +
  geom_density() +
  facet_wrap(~year)

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Show annual transition

library(gganimate)

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, col = species)) +
  geom_density() +
  transition_time(year) +
  ggtitle('Year: {frame_time}')

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Add history

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, col = species)) +
  geom_density() +
  transition_time(year) +
  ggtitle('Year: {frame_time}') +
  shadow_wake(wake = 0.3, wrap = FALSE)

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Modify transition speed

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, col = species)) +
  geom_density() +
  transition_time(year) +
  ggtitle('Year: {frame_time}') +
  ease_aes("quintic-in-out")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Have axes follow data

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, col = species)) +
  geom_density() +
  transition_time(year) +
  ggtitle('Year: {frame_time}') +
  view_follow()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Save file

anim_save("~/Desktop/test_anim.gif")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
slabinterval

penguins %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species)) +
  stat_slabinterval()




This plots a “halfeye” plot with a density distribution and a line at the bottom showing the mean and quantiles of the data.
Note that we didn’t have to create any new objects; stat_slabinterval automatically calculates densities and summary statistics. There are corresponding geom_* functions for already summarized data.
Other plot types within ggdist are variations on the stat_slabinterval theme.
Often you’ll want to use these shortcuts instead of building something up out of scratch.

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Example: dotsinterval

penguins %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species)) +
  stat_dotsinterval()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Example: interval

penguins %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species)) +
  stat_interval()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Example: interval

penguins %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species)) +
  stat_interval() +
  scale_color_brewer()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Combining elements: Raincloud plots

penguins %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g, y = species)) +
  stat_slabinterval() +
  stat_dotsinterval(side = "bottom")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Ribbon plots
stat_lineribbon plots quantile intervals around a line automatically:

penguins %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = body_mass_g)) +
  stat_lineribbon() +
  scale_fill_brewer() +
  facet_wrap(vars(species))

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Ribbon plots
You can control the bands using the .width argument:

penguins %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = body_mass_g)) +
  stat_lineribbon(.width = c(.8, .97, .99)) +
  scale_fill_brewer() +
  facet_wrap(vars(species))

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Ribbon plots
.width = ppoints() creates a gradient:

penguins %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = body_mass_g, fill = after_stat(.width))) +
  stat_lineribbon(.width = ppoints(100)) +
  scale_fill_distiller() +
  facet_wrap(vars(species))

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Visualizing frequentist model output
Combined with the broom and distributional packages, ggdist can display frequentist model uncertainty.

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Visualizing frequentist model output

library(broom)
library(distributional)

penguin_lm <- lm(body_mass_g ~  species, data = penguins)

broom::tidy(penguin_lm)

# A tibble: 3 × 5
  term             estimate std.error statistic   p.value
  <chr>               <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>
1 (Intercept)        3706.       38.1    97.2   6.88e-245
2 speciesChinstrap     26.9      67.7     0.398 6.91e-  1
3 speciesGentoo      1386.       56.9    24.4   1.01e- 75

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Visualizing frequentist model output

broom::tidy(penguin_lm) |>
  ggplot(aes(y = term)) +
    stat_halfeye(
      aes(xdist = dist_student_t(df = df.residual(penguin_lm), 
                                 mu = estimate, 
                                 sigma = std.error))
    )

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Visualizing frequentist model output

You can also use ribbons to show uncertainty around lines of fit.
We’ll need a linear model with a continuous predictor.
And we’ll use tidyr::expand and broom::augment to get the predicted line of fit from the model.

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Visualizing frequentist model output

penguin_lm_cont <- lm(body_mass_g ~  year + species, data = penguins)

penguin_lm_cont_fitted <- penguins %>%
  group_by(species) %>%
  tidyr::expand(year = seq(min(year), max(year), length.out = 3)) %>%
  augment(penguin_lm_cont, newdata = ., se_fit = TRUE) 

head(penguin_lm_cont_fitted) 

# A tibble: 6 × 4
  species    year .fitted .se.fit
  <fct>     <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
1 Adelie     2007   3703.    50.4
2 Adelie     2008   3706.    38.2
3 Adelie     2009   3709.    48.2
4 Chinstrap  2007   3730.    63.6
5 Chinstrap  2008   3733.    56.0
6 Chinstrap  2009   3737.    64.5

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Visualizing frequentist model output

  ggplot(penguin_lm_cont_fitted, aes(x = year)) +
  stat_lineribbon(
    aes(ydist = dist_student_t(df = df.residual(penguin_lm_cont), 
                               mu = .fitted, 
                               sigma = .se.fit))) +
  facet_wrap(vars(species)) +
  scale_fill_brewer()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Visualizing Bayesian model components

ggdist plots are great for visualizing Bayesian model components:

priors
posterior draws
posterior predictions

We can fit a simple Bayesian linear model and visualize the posterior…

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Fitting a model

library(brms)
library(tidybayes)

penguins_brm <- brm(body_mass_g ~ species, data = penguins, iter = 1000)

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Extracting draws from the posterior

penguins_brm %>%
tidybayes::gather_draws(
c(b_Intercept,
b_speciesChinstrap,
b_speciesGentoo)
) |>
head() 

# A tibble: 6 × 5
# Groups:   .variable [1]
  .chain .iteration .draw .variable   .value
   <int>      <int> <int> <chr>        <dbl>
1      1          1     1 b_Intercept  3646.
2      1          2     2 b_Intercept  3680.
3      1          3     3 b_Intercept  3694.
4      1          4     4 b_Intercept  3688.
5      1          5     5 b_Intercept  3632.
6      1          6     6 b_Intercept  3779.

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Posterior draws rainclouds

penguins_brm |>
tidybayes::gather_draws(
c(b_Intercept,
b_speciesChinstrap,
b_speciesGentoo)) %>%
ggplot(aes(y = .variable, x = .value)) +  
  geom_dotsinterval(side = "bottom", dotsize = .05) + 
  stat_slabinterval()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Takeaways

ggdist contains geom and stat functions for plotting distributions.
Slab functions show variations on density plots.
Ribbons show variation around a line.
ggdist plays nicely with Bayesian and frequentist modeling frameworks.

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
ggraph

For plotting networks, graphs, and trees
Adds layouts and geoms for nodes and edges
Integrates with tidygraph to wrap around numerous other graph object types (igraph, dedrogram, hclust, graph, phylo, …)

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Example: Mouse data
Begin by loading network data, in this case from the graphml format.
Data from So et al. 2015, in the Animal Social Networks Repository.

library(igraph)
library(tidygraph)

mouse_sniffing <- read_graph(here::here("2024", "03-extensions", "mouse_so_grooming_network.graphml"),
format = "graphml")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Example: as_tbl_graph
tidygraph::as_tbl_graph standardizes different graph storage formats.

mouse_graph <- mouse_sniffing |>
as_tbl_graph()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Plotting mouse sniffing data

ggraph(mouse_graph, layout = 'kk') + 
    geom_edge_fan() + 
    geom_node_point() +
    theme_minimal() +
    ggtitle("Mouse sniffs")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Alternate layouts

ggraph(mouse_graph, layout = 'eigen') + 
    geom_edge_fan() + 
    geom_node_point() +
    theme_minimal() +
    ggtitle("Mouse sniffs")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Alternate layouts

ggraph(mouse_graph, layout = 'linear', circular = TRUE) + 
    geom_edge_fan() + 
    geom_node_point() +
    theme_minimal() +
    ggtitle("Mouse sniffs")

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Example: phylogenies

ggraph can plot phylogenetic trees.
We’ll get a phylogeny using the R Open Tree of Life (rotl) and plot it.

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text: Getting a phylogeny

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Getting a phylogeny

library(rotl)
rodent_id <- tnrs_match_names("Heteromyidae")
rodent_tree <- tol_subtree(ott_id = ott_id(rodent_id))


Progress [----------------------------------] 0/11 (  0) ?s
Progress [================================] 11/11 (100)  0s
                                                            

rodent_tree$node.label <- c(1:64)
class(rodent_tree)

[1] "phylo"

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
section: Convert the phylogeny to a graph
text:
Convert the phylogeny to a graph

rodent_graph <- as_tbl_graph(rodent_tree)

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Dendrogram

ggraph(rodent_graph, "dendrogram") +
geom_edge_link()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Unrooted tree

ggraph(rodent_graph, "unrooted") +
geom_edge_link()

title: Exploring the Wide World of ggplot2 Extensions
text:
Takeaways

ggraph can plot many different types of network objects.
Use as_tbl_graph to convert graphs to ggraph-compatible objects.
Layouts strongly determine the appearance and interpretability of a graph.
